One of my favorite childhood memories is coming home from school or soccer practice to the sound of metal utensils clanging and scraping against the sides of a wok as my dad cooked alongside recorded (VHS!) episodes of Martin Yan's "Yan Can Cook." My dad was an incredible cook, and obsessed with the flavors of Asian cuisine in particular (also, I was never allowed to touch his Chinese cleaver). So, in honor of him ‚Äî and because grilling season has arrived and you're desperately in need of another go-to recipe ‚Äî I partnered with @KikkomanUSA and @Allrecipes to make a dish I know my dad would love.
-
This Honey-Glazed Chinese Chicken is crazy delicious and the recipe, featuring the iconic Kikkoman¬Æ Teriyaki Marinade & Sauce, is so simple. I like to bake these drumsticks about 3/4 of the way through and then finish them on the grill just before serving. Serve with grilled veggies, on top of rice or noodles, or even pull off the chicken and use as a filling for tacos or lettuce wraps. Also can confirm: The marinade works just as well with wings or boneless chicken thighs.
-
Grab the recipe on¬†Allrecipes.com

Pro tip: Don‚Äôt wait until your 30s (with two hyperactive kids) to get your wisdom teeth taken out. It‚Äôs just a terrible idea. My two saviors, however: The NCAA basketball tournament, and ‚Äî after a couple days of yogurt, bone broth and applesauce ‚Äî savory oatmeal. Honestly, it‚Äôs the only way I‚Äôll eat oatmeal. My favorite version, pictured here, starts with steel cut oats and includes soy sauce (or liquid aminos), spicy chili crisp (or any type of chili oil), furikake, chives and an egg yolk. Once I was mostly recovered and graduated from baby food, I started adding vinegar-cooked greens like bok choy or Chinese mustard greens. And if you‚Äôre not cool with the raw yolk thing, a poached or fried egg works just as well.

Need some holiday dinner inspo? How about Orecchiette w/ Sausage and Broccoli Rabe... served family style in a skillet... with BURRATA. This is my go-to (not authentic, I‚Äôm aware) version of one of my favorite all-time dishes... the burrata gets stirred in at the table just before eating and instantly melts to create a creamy, cheesy sauce. Bonus: There‚Äôs just enough red and green in here for it to officially qualify as ‚ÄúChristmas pasta.‚Äù Recipe below!
-
1 lb. Orecchiette pasta
2 tablespoons Extra Virgin Olive Oil (plus more for garnish)
1 lb. Italian-style pork or chicken sausage
3 garlic cloves, minced
Crushed Calabrian chili flakes (can substitute red pepper flakes), to taste
1 bunch broccoli rabe, stems trimmed and leaves chopped
Sea salt, to taste
Juice and zest from 1 lemon
1/2 cup freshly grated Pecorino or Parmesan cheese
1/2 cup bread crumbs, store-bought or homemade
8 ounces burrata cheese (if it‚Äôs a ball and not scoopable, cut into small pieces)
-
1. Cook pasta in a large pot of boiling salted water, according to package directions, just until ‚Ä™al dente‚Ä¨. Reserve the pasta water.
2. Meanwhile, heat oil in a heavy large skillet over medium heat. Add the sausage, garlic and chili flakes and cook, breaking up the sausage with a spoon or potato masher, until browned. Transfer sausage mixture to a plate.
3. Add broccoli rabe to the same pan and sautee for 2-3 min, just until tender. Deglaze with a cup of reserved pasta water, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of ‚Ä™the pan‚Ä¨.
4. Add sausage mixture and pasta to ‚Ä™the pan‚Ä¨ and stir well to combine over low heat, adjusting the consistency with more of the reserved pasta water, if needed. Season to taste with salt.
5. Remove from heat and stir in lemon juice and grated cheese. Place burrata cheese in the center, then top with bread crumbs, lemon zest, more chili flakes and a drizzle of olive oil.
6. Bring the skillet to the table and, while still hot, toss the burrata until creamy and stringy and the pasta is completely coated. Divide the pasta among shallow bowls and serve with extra bread crumbs and chili flakes on the side for guests.

Toasted Coconut. Pretzel. Peanut Butter.  I try not to play favorites with my homemade nut butters... but this one, as the wife would say, is beyond. Delicious with apples, spread on toast (also: stuffed inside of french toast), stirred into yogurt or ice cream... or eaten straight out of the jar with a massive spoon. I wrote down a recipe. Here you go:
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
1 (16 oz) jar roasted peanuts, unsalted or lightly salted
2 cups mini pretzels (regular or gluten free)
1 cup shredded unsweetened coconut
Honey or Agave (optional)
Sea Salt
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
1. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Toast the coconut for 5-7 minutes, or until lightly golden brown. Let cool for 10 minutes.

2. Place peanuts in the bowl of a food processor and process for approximately 5 minutes or until creamy and smooth, scraping down sides as needed.

3. Add pretzels, toasted coconut and honey/agave, if using, and pulse several times until desired texture is reached ‚Äî you still want to see and feel bits of pretzel and coconut. Taste and add salt, if needed (will depend on which peanuts are used and personal preference).
*
[another option for the above step is chopping the coconut and pretzels by hand, and then stirring them into the peanut butter along with the honey/agave ‚Äî adding sea salt at the very end, to taste]
*
4. Store in an airtight jar or container at room temperature for up to several weeks (trust me though, it‚Äôll be gone well before then).
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

Spicy cauliflower tortillas: That guilt-free solution for stuffing your face on #TacoTuesday (also, every other day). Had a lot of requests for the recipe after my previous post... so, I skipped work, locked the kids in their rooms and ignored my wife for most of the day just so I could write down this recipe and share it with you. It's cauliflower, eggs and a few seasonings (I included my favs, but feel free to do your own thing). These are soft, very pliable and fold just as well as most corn tortillas. And they‚Äôre healthy and stuff, which is kinda cool in moderation.
‚Ä¢
1 head of cauliflower, cut into florets and stems removed
2 eggs
1-2 canned chipotle peppers in adobo sauce, seeds removed, finely chopped (can subtitute 1 tablespoon good quality chile powder)
1/4 cup freshly grated cotija or parmesan cheese (optional)
1 teaspoon lime zest (optional)
1/2 teaspoon dried oregano (optional)
salt and pepper, to taste
‚Ä¢
1) Preheat oven to 375 degrees.
2) Add the cauliflower to the bowl of a food processor and pulse until texture is similar to rice (even a bit finer, like couscous)
3) Transfer cauliflower rice to a microwave-safe bowl and microwave for 2 minutes. Stir, then microwave for another 2 minutes and stir again.
4) Place the cauliflower in a cheesecloth or dish towel and squeeze out as much water as you can (be careful, it‚Äôs hot)
5) Transfer drained cauliflower back to a bowl and add remaining ingredients. Mix until well combined.
6) Separate the mixture into 6 equal sized balls, then spread each onto a parchment-lined baking sheet to make 6 flat circles.
7) Place in the oven to bake for 10 minutes, carefully flip each tortilla, then return to the oven for an additional 5 to 7 minutes. Let cool slightly.
8) Heat a cast iron pan over medium heat. Place tortillas in the pan, pressing down gently until lightly golden, 1-2 minutes per side.

Fact: When using cauliflower tortillas, one can justifiably consume twice as many tacos. These are stuffed with braised turkey thighs (Thanksgiving leftover ideas!), roasted mushrooms, vinegar-cooked greens, avocado, feta and spicy chimichurri sauce and served on homemade red chile cauliflower tortillas [I add pur√©ed chipotle in adobo and grated cotija/parmesan into my tortilla mixture, which automatically makes them the best ever].
Why does this Kimchi Bacon Cheeseburger with fried egg and gochujang mayo look like it‚Äôs about to spit the hottest verse of 2017?

Pro tip: If you‚Äôre going to go through all the effort of making spicy fried chicken sandwiches [w/ horseradish cheddar, pickles, buffalo sauce and avocado ranch on a @kingshawaiian bun] ... you should probably make a few extra and stash them in the fridge. They reheat really well in the waffle iron, and you‚Äôll be extremely grateful the next time you and your significant other drink several bottles of wine and can barely get out of bed (see: today).

Sometimes you prepare a meal, and then take several photos of said meal in order to satisfy your twisted food fetish. Other times, you dress up your entire family in food costumes and politely ask someone else to take pictures while you watch. I have problems. Happy trick-or-treating, everyone.

The ‚ÄúPescado Zarandeado‚Äù from @coniseafood: In my opinion, still one of the single most epic dishes in all of LA. Butterflied and grilled whole snook served with caramelized onions, fresh tortillas and a side of spicy green (jalape√±o) sauce. It‚Äôs a very messy and equally satisfying make-your-own-fish-tacos experience. Also, I believe this is meant to be shared. I never share. Get your own fish.

‚ÄúShu-mai, don‚Äôt bother me...‚Äù [fun fact: I sing and/or hum that üî• self-written remix literally every time we‚Äôre eating dumplings and the shumai hits the table... and every time, my wife shakes her head in embarrassment/regret. Obviously doesn‚Äôt realize my #dadjokes are all that and dim sum üôÑ].

Ate a ton of amazing food this past weekend in Seattle. Didn‚Äôt post or even take photos/video of 99% of it. I have to say, it was pretty liberating. Also discovered that I prefer warm food over cold food. That said, the one time I felt obligated to pull out my phone (in the pouring rain) was for @corazontruck... and specifically these Vampiro tacos w/ carne asada, melted cheese, avocado salsa, smoked chile mayo, cilantro and onion on a crispy handmade tortilla (yeah, these dudes are making all the corn and flour tortillas from scratch in the truck). Some of the friendliest guys you‚Äôll ever meet, and some of the best tacos I‚Äôve had outside of LA.

Still the best burrito I‚Äôve eaten all year (because homemade is always better): Breakfast burrito with Dungeness crab fried rice, Chinese garlic spinach, caramelized kimchi chorizo (Kimchorizo‚Ñ¢), soft-scrambled eggs and Oaxacan cheese, rolled up tightly and pressed in the cast iron with coconut oil.

In honor of #NationalPastaDay, a loose interpretation of what is possibly my favorite all-time pasta dish: Bucatini all'Amatriciana. This one starts with a spicy tomato sauce (and a LOT of pancetta and garlic), and I finish it with pecorino, smoked olive oil and an egg yolk... which is all just a more eloquent and socially acceptable way of saying: I made bacon, egg and cheese pasta.

Because I once read in a book somewhere that eating spicy, sweat-inducing foods actually makes you feel cooler (literally and figuratively), here's a Quinoa Chicken Curry Bowl to help beat this October heat. It's loaded with braised chicken, eggplant, tomatoes, garlic, ginger and garam masala... and topped with brown rice, crushed almonds and cilantro. No butter. No cream. It's Indian food with less attitude [bonus: my kids love it].

Packed the wife a lunch today (then made her take a photo with it, obviously). Here‚Äôs the shaved turkey sandwich w/ chipotle gouda, smashed avo, lettuce, tomato and spicy greek yogurt caesar dressing on grilled country bread. You know you did it right when the avocado is seeping through the holes in the bread.

My go-to brunch strategies: 1) Order the most unique item on the menu 2) Order one of everything on the menu. Basically did both at @greatwhitevenice, with the most unique dish being these corn fritters with charred avocado salsa, green chiles and a poached egg [and if you ask really politely, they‚Äôll stack a few thick slices of grilled halloumi cheese on there].
Still the best $5 lunch/dinner/2am meal in LA. Don‚Äôt fight me on this. #NationalTacoDay üåÆ

Late Saturday nights call for Sunday morning Waffled Bao breakfast sandwiches. Steamed Chinese BBQ pork bun (Char Siu Bao), cut in half, stuffed with scrambled egg + cheese + caramelized kimchi + hoisin + sriracha... pressed in the waffle iron (with fingers crossed). If you don‚Äôt have access to fresh or frozen Bao, store-bought biscuit dough works just as well [use two biscuit rounds, roll out or flatten with hands, layer fillings on one biscuit round, top with second and pinch all the way around to seal before pressing in waffle iron on medium heat].

Because Cuban-Japanese fusion is so hot right now [heavy sarcasm] ... here‚Äôs my Katsu-Cubano sandwich (aka The Katsubano‚Ñ¢). It's layered with traditional chicken katsu, honey ham, swiss cheese, pickled cucumber-wakame salad, jalape√±o mustard and katsu sauce on panini-pressed ciabatta. 2018: Year of the Dog... and #Cubanese cuisine.
Confirmed: These spicy lobster nachos remain one of the single most satisfying ways to crush your diet (and wallet) while at @disneyland.

Whenever I act a bit childish (rare), dive into a plate of food with reckless abandon (often), or laugh uncontrollably at my horrendous #dadjokes (never, because they‚Äôre all awesome), my wife asks if she‚Äôs married to a 5-year-old... and I‚Äôm like, ‚Äúuh, I don‚Äôt know... are you?‚Äù She never changes the number. We‚Äôve been together 16 years, and I‚Äôm still 5? Doesn‚Äôt add up. Anyway, today this dude turns 5 and I couldn‚Äôt be more jealous... or more proud of the little man he‚Äôs becoming. Happy 5th birthday, buddy. Welcome to the club.

When in San Diego, one must @getcrackshacked. There's literally nothing on this menu I wouldn't order (salads included), but my go-to is the "Firebird" sandwich: Spicy fried thigh, cool ranch, crispy onions and pickles on a potato roll. I added a generous layer of their housemade Kimchi BBQ sauce underneath the chicken... because it was there and seemed like the right thing to do.
Will drive for #SpicyPie. This should hold me over until Coachella 2018. @kaaboodelmar
Things I order 100% of the time if on the menu: Crispy ahi tuna tacos with avocado and spicy mayo [not pictured: the first order of tuna tacos].

Portobello "benedict" with garlic spinach, oven-roasted yellow tomatoes, poached egg, basil pesto-creme fraiche, aleppo pepper, meyer lemon zest and smoked sea salt. In the weeks leading up to our recent trip, as sort of a mock anniversary gift to myself (and my wife, let's be honest)... I challenged myself to get back down to my wedding weight from 10 years ago. I (mostly) cut out carbs, cheese and alcohol, and hit the gym almost every day... sometimes twice. The results: 20 lbs in 30 days, actually surpassing my goal (and then I went to Greece and ate gyros for two weeks). Is that diet sustainable for me? Clearly not. But I had the discipline to do it... and I saw major results... and I didn't die or severely injure anyone. So that has to count for something. #30DayAnniversaryChallenge [start the movement].

My camera roll is currently jam-packed with gyro and souvlaki pics like this... which is what happens when you eat an average of like 2.3 per day for two weeks. We had some excellent versions of this Greek street food staple on the islands, but I still think the best (and also: worst) gyro and souvlaki can be found in Athens. Fittingly, the chicken and pork gyro seen here were the final meal of our trip. It's also one of the few times we ate them completely sober and before 2am [free food photography tips: Natural lighting + Sobriety = Superior quality photos]

If you've been following my stories, you know I have a thing for places that are off the beaten path. This breakfast spot in Mykonos was a bit of a hike, but such a hidden gem... and these soft-scrambled eggs with truffles, avocado mousse and roasted cherry tomatoes on housemade wheat toast were some of the best I've had from a restaurant (although I could've done without the random enoki mushroom). The secret to getting that creamy consistency: Greek yogurt! Can't wait to get home and give this a go in my kitchen. Actually, I'm in no rush to get home, but when I do...

The first time @mysequinlife and I tried octopus was 10 years ago in Mykonos. It was braised in red wine, and so incredible we ordered another one for dessert. The massive piece of octopus pictured here (from @scorpiosmyk) was cooked sous vide, marinated in Greek olive oil and herbs, and then charred on the BBQ. It was spork tender and completely perfect. Hard to say if it's the best I've ever had, but certainly top 3.
How to hack a Greek hotel breakfast buffet: Open-faced sandwich with bacon, roasted tomatoes w/ melted gruyere, spicy tzatziki and a fried egg on toasted country bread.
